header.title: Diarrhea Discordia Volume II/ INTERMITTENS
authors: Tabula Rasa, KSC El Kabong Kabal
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Chaos Magic, Discordianism

central_thesis: The zine explores the nature of 'weirdness' in the modern information age, arguing that while overt strangeness has become commonplace due to information saturation and the rise of niche subcultures, a deeper 'High Weirdness' persists. This underlying reality is a syncretic blend of occult theories, alien phenomena, cult activities, and hidden power structures that constantly blur the lines between fiction, folklore, and consensus reality. The text suggests that true 'weirdness' lies in challenging uncritical belief and rigid patterns of thought, advocating for individual acts of creative chaos, skeptical engagement with anomalous phenomena, and a form of cognitive self-programming as paths to personal liberation and resistance against both external manipulation and internal dogmatism.

structure_content.summary: This origin myth describes Zaurn, an entity sent by EIEIO (Great Kaos), who teaches 'Hairless Apes' (humanity) language, writing, and moral concepts. This act paradoxically frees and ensnares their minds, as naming creates existence but also binds thought, necessitating 'true imagination and magick to break beyond'.

A pseudo-academic report presenting a 'creative writing test' (dream diary) from a 'Borderline Simpleton' patient. The dreams are mundane but reveal underlying anxieties, framed within a context of 'Low Intelligence Disorders' and 'lower frequency brainwaves,' subtly hinting at altered states of perception.

A narrative about a homeless artist who only dances chaotically in the rain, an act of uninhibited personal expression that subverts mundane reality. The piece highlights the overlooked 'sparkle' of the city in the rain, contrasting it with the hurried, unseeing populace, framing the dance as a ritual of spontaneous rebellion.

A fragmented, stream-of-consciousness text that weaves together seemingly random associations, esoteric concepts ('21st Century Barbelith,' 'magic fiction,' 'lopsided Pineal Glands'), pop culture, and political commentary. It challenges linear narrative and logical coherence, reflecting a chaotic and syncretic worldview, culminating in an Orwellian reference to a delayed, insidious control.

Presents a 'program' of instructions for the 'central nervous system' on how to interpret reality, distinguishing personal thoughts from external 'radio transmissions from the overmind' or 'psychic archetypal communications from Speaker of the House Carl Jung.' It outlines a method for defending 'pedestrian belief in reality' by classifying 'breaches' as insignificant or insanity, and then 'deleting breach from memory,' functioning as a meta-cognitive control protocol.

Analyzes the contemporary era where information saturation has normalized 'weirdness,' leading to a loss of a central 'abnormal.' It argues that while this fosters diverse subcultures ('eclectically ecstatic, subculturally pragmatic'), it also desensitizes individuals to genuine novelty. The piece implies that 'Operation Mindfuck' is less impactful as everything becomes strange, yet finds a new relevance in the collective embrace of individual 'weirdness'.

A satirical, anti-astrology 'horoscope' featuring absurd signs (Yeti, Tube Sock, Preacher, Fairy, Republican) and traditional zodiac signs, each delivering cynical, chaotic, or darkly humorous advice and predictions. It critiques conventional belief systems by offering irreverent and transgressive interpretations of cosmic influence, emphasizing individual agency over predetermined fate.

A darkly humorous first-person account of performing a transgressive magical ritual to win back an ex-lover. It involves acquiring and ritually butchering a sheep, using its blood and remains to create a shocking display at the ex's home. The 'ritual' yields the desired outcome, illustrating a chaotic magical practice fueled by intense emotion and the violation of social taboos.

A humorous depiction of a fictional 'Spaganaki ritual' presented with pseudo-anthropological seriousness. It parodies sacred indigenous ceremonies by infusing them with absurd elements like a 'high-five maneuver' and a 'bacon explosion,' embodying Discordian irreverence towards traditional spiritual forms.

A chaotic montage of fragmented TV snippets depicting a reality saturated with fear, conspiracy theories, bizarre news, religious extremism, and absurd advertisements. It portrays a world of information overload and engineered confusion, highlighting a 'scarring' that reveals a deeper, manipulated truth beneath the surface chaos, framed by an 'Enlightenment without Sunlight' via a 'Firewall'.

A satirical advice column by 'MILFs, Jenne and Khara,' offering aggressively cynical and anti-conventional guidance on child-rearing. The advice, delivered with shock humor and transgressive suggestions, subverts traditional parenting norms, advocating for harsh self-reliance, self-defense, and ignoring perceived misbehavior.

structure_content.chapter_title: A Poem for the Strange Times
structure_content.summary: A poem reflecting on the historical and contemporary experience of living in 'Strange Times,' where societal changes (from agriculture to the digital era) constantly redefine 'weirdness.' It expresses a melancholic view of progress, questioning whether advancements truly lead to improvement or simply different forms of chaos and disillusionment.

The most extensive occult analysis, this 'dissertation' explores 'High Weirdness' as a syncretic web connecting Lovecraftian mythos (Necronomicon, Old Ones), historical occultists (Crowley, Grant, Parsons, Hubbard), UFO phenomena (Lam as Grey Alien archetype), cults (Temple of Set, Four Pi Movement, Scientology, Moonies), unexplained animal mutilations, and the occult significance of Sirius. It argues that the danger lies in uncritical belief and advocates for skepticism, critical faculties, and laughter against manipulative narratives.

A satirical declaration by the 'Germain Cabal of Germans' proclaiming 2009 the 'Year of Nothing,' encouraging 'Discordians' to observe it by choosing 'the nothing to do of their choice.' It parodies bureaucratic pronouncements and societal expectations of productivity, embracing nihilism and non-action.

structure_content.chapter_title: 101 Ways to Make Everybody's Day Weirder
structure_content.summary: A practical manual offering 101 instructions for injecting chaos, absurdity, and 'weirdness' into daily life. These acts, ranging from social pranks to personal subversions of routine, are designed to challenge social norms, disrupt consensus reality, and encourage creative, non-linear engagement with the mundane, embodying a personal 'Operation Mindfuck.' A meta-warning from a 'Ministry of Security' further frames these acts as subversive.

key_concepts.definition: A primordial entity or principle responsible for gifting language, writing, and moral/social concepts to humanity, leading to the dual outcome of mental liberation and ensnarement through the act of definition and labeling.
The ultimate divine entity in the Discordian creation myth, embodying the paradoxical nature of existence and responsible for the inherent freedom and constraint of human thought.

key_concepts.term: If It Is Not Named: It Does Not Exist
key_concepts.definition: A fundamental metaphysical principle introduced by Zaurn, asserting that the act of naming or defining brings something into existential being, highlighting the creative power of language and thought in shaping reality.

A literal, programmable protocol for the human mind, akin to a magical sigil or a set of axioms for reality construction, designed to filter perception, differentiate internal thoughts from external influences, and maintain a baseline 'pedestrian belief in reality'.

External, potentially manipulative, psychic, or spiritual influences that are to be identified and excluded from one's personal thoughts and internal monologue, as part of the CNS programming protocol.
The consensus or baseline reality that the meta-cognitive system seeks to defend, implying a stable, conventional understanding of the world against anomalous 'breaches'.

An anomalous event or perception that deviates from 'pedestrian belief in reality,' which must be categorized (as 'not salient or significant' or 'insanity') and managed, ideally by deletion from memory, to maintain mental coherence.

A comprehensive term encompassing the interconnected phenomena of occultism, ufology, conspiracy theories, cults, and anomalies that challenge conventional reality, revealing a syncretic and often paradoxical nature of the modern world. The danger is not the weirdness itself, but uncritical belief in it.

A Kabbalistic concept, representing the 'shells' or unbalanced forces of the Tree of Life. In the text, it is presented as a realm accessible through occult practice from which Lovecraftian 'Old Ones' can be invoked.

A being invoked by Aleister Crowley, identified in the text as an archetypal precursor or representation of the 'little Grey aliens' of modern ufology, illustrating a syncretic link between historical occultism and contemporary alien encounters.

A Discordian concept and practical approach aimed at subverting consensus reality, challenging dogmatic beliefs, and promoting individual liberation through acts of absurdity, chaos, and non-linear communication. In the text, it applies to both mental programming and everyday disruptive acts.

A satirical Discordian concept for a year declared by the 'Germain Cabal of Germans' where individuals are encouraged to embrace nihilism or the void by choosing 'the nothing to do of their choice,' subverting conventional goal-setting and productivity.

practical_system.description: The text outlines a two-pronged practical system for operative magic and reality manipulation, rooted in Discordian philosophy and Chaos Magic principles. The first aspect focuses on internal, cognitive programming to manage perception and belief, while the second involves external, performative acts to inject chaos and subversion into daily life. Both aim to challenge consensus reality, disrupt fixed patterns of thought, and foster individual liberation from dogmatism and external control.
tools: Index Card and Wallet: For containing and 'forgetting' the Central Nervous System protocol, thereby embedding its instructions into the subconscious.

Henckels 8-inch Chef Knife, Live Sheep, Bucket, Plastic Bag: Specific implements for the transgressive manifestation ritual, emphasizing a direct, physical engagement with the act of sacrifice and symbolic display.

Everyday Objects and Social Interactions: The primary tools for the '101 Ways' – including clothes, telephones, notes, refrigerators, office supplies, and various forms of communication – utilized in unconventional and disruptive ways.

Critical Faculties, Skepticism, and Laughter: Essential intellectual and emotional tools for navigating 'High Weirdness,' preventing uncritical belief, and maintaining mental agility against manipulative narratives (page 40).
rituals: The 'Central Nervous System' Protocol: A meta-cognitive programming ritual involving conscious interpretation of experiences, differentiation of internal monologue from external/occult influences, and the systematic classification and 'deletion from memory' of 'breaches' to maintain a 'pedestrian belief in reality.' The ritual concludes with a command to forget the instructions themselves, acting as a sigil-like embedding (page 9).

Transgressive Manifestation Ritual: A highly emotional and taboo-breaking working intended to force a desired outcome. This involves symbolic sacrifice (acquiring and butchering a live sheep), the use of its bodily fluids (blood) and remains in a shocking, psychologically impactful display at the target's location (an ex-lover's home), designed to disrupt their reality and manipulate their emotional state for a specific magical purpose (page 16-17).

Everyday Weirdness Acts ('101 Ways'): A diverse collection of disruptive, absurd, and playful actions designed to be performed in daily life. These acts serve as a continuous 'Operation Mindfuck,' challenging social norms, personal routines, and the collective consensus reality. Examples include changing clothes mid-day and denying it, answering the phone with arbitrary questions, hiding odd objects in mailboxes or fridges, performing spontaneous public acts, and peculiar social interactions (pages 43-48).

relevant_quotes.text: EIEIO, the Great Kaos, had sent Zaurn the Grey to the Hairless Apes to both free and ensnare their minds: giving them the gifts of speech and communication so that they may be able to form thoughts and thus become more than they are;, while at the same time having these thoughts bind and constrict their ideas, through endless labeling and defining so that it takes true imagination and magick to break beyond.

The instructions to the central nervous system are as follows: +Interpret humanlike physical appearance accompanied by humanlike behavior =as evidence of Humanity. +Interpret your internal monologue =as your own thoughts &and not{ #radio transmissions from the overmind #psychic archetypal communications from Speaker of the House Carl Jung (...) #extrapolations of circuit activity within your positronic processing brain unit} +Defend current pedestrian belief in reality or current eigenstate &tools{ #classification of breach as something --not salient or significant #classification of breach as insanity --not attributable to <+> #[delta] attention; delete breach from memory} !++Put this card back in your wallet and forget that you took it out

Ironically, there's no weirdness left in the Strange Times. It all disappeared when it became commonplace. So many people are defining their own norms that there is no abnormal anymore. We're eclectically ecstatic, subculturally pragmatic.
Your sign still sucks. Seriously, kill yourself.
A: Well, the first thing that you need to do is find a good piece of God. I usually suggest a 6 lb cut from the rump area (Exodus 33:20-23).
He totally gave me the eyeball, but he couldn't come up with a decent argument in the face of my explanation...
If the universe has no end, then the asshole is everywhere.

Professor Cramulus brings us some stunning photographs from a rarely seen Spaganaki ritual. The sheer majesty of the dance is breathtaking yet it isn't done easily. The chief must burrow especially deep to pull off the high-five maneuver. When asked about his experience amongst the Spaganaki, the Professor said, 'It was a very rewarding experience, but I totally came when they brought out the bacon explosion.'
The scarring is the most telling thing.
Enlightenment without Sunlight? Firewall window to outside world
Maybe if she wasn't such a little tease, your kid wouldn't get spit on. Didn't you know this is how boys treat girls who don't put out?
Guaranteed Fear and Loathing. Abandon all hope. Prepare for the Weirdness. Get familiar with Cannibalism.
The belief is, and the belief is the danger.
Dumb. It is the beginning of the end of our world as we knew it. Doom is the operative ethic.

critical_analysis.relevance: This work is highly relevant to contemporary Western Esotericism, particularly Chaos Magic and post-modern occultism. It directly addresses the impact of information overload and cultural fragmentation on magical practice and the perception of reality. The zine critiques dogmatism in both mundane and esoteric contexts, proposing fluid, adaptable, and often humorous approaches to understanding and manipulating reality. It contextualizes modern 'weirdness' within historical occult traditions, highlighting syncretic connections between disparate phenomena (Lovecraft, Crowley, UFOs, cults), and ultimately advocates for a critically engaged, yet playfully chaotic, interaction with the world.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of practitioners of Chaos Magic, Discordians, and those interested in post-modern occultism. It also appeals to counter-culture enthusiasts, critical thinkers exploring alternative realities, and individuals seeking to subvert mundane routines through acts of creative chaos. The content demands an audience comfortable with irony, satire, dark humor, and transgressive themes, and capable of discerning meta-commentary from literal instruction.
